sub_title: Award-winning author & Professor of Governance of Sustainability Transitions
summary:
Prof. Dr. Patrick Huntjens is award-winning author of ‘Towards a Natural Social Contract’ (2021), for which he received the prestigious Nautilus Book Award (Gold Medal) for best book of the year 2022 in the category 'World Cultures' Transformational Growth and Development'.

Patrick is Professor of Governance of Sustainability Transitions, Maastricht Sustainability Institute (MSI), School of Business and Economics (SBE), Maastricht University.

Patrick is also Professor of Social Innovation & Governance for Sustainability at Inholland University of Applied Sciences. In this role, he was awarded the national title ‘Professor of the Year 2021’. 

He currently serves as Chairman of the Round Table Food Transition (2021-2025) by DuurzaamDoor, a multistakeholder knowledge and innovation programme by the Netherlands Government.

For the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES), United Nations, he serves as lead author of the Transformative Change Assessment (2022-2024).

Patrick has a multi-disciplinary background in Complex System Sciences and Policy Sciences (PhD Magna Cum Laude), in Political Science & International Relations (MSc Cum Laude), and in Biology/Ecology (MSc). For his PhD dissertation (2010) he collaborated with Prof. Dr. Elinor Ostrom, the first woman in history receiving the Nobel Prize in Economics. 

With 24 years of professional experience in the public, private and civil society sector, and on-the-ground work experience in more than 45 countries, Patrick’s work focuses on societal transformation, system innovations, and sustainability transitions at multiple levels (global to local). He is spearheading a Research and Innovation Agenda with a core focus on the Governance of Sustainability Transitions, with specific attention for issues of politics, power and justice in transitions, and drawing on the wider field of governance, commons, innovation and transition studies as well as other fields like complexity theory and systems theory. Ongoing research activities include 1) Transition to a sustainable and healthy agri-food system, 2) Governance of urban sustainability transitions, and 3) Transition to circular and regenerative economies and cultures.

He served as an advisor to the World Bank, United Nations, European Commission, various governments, and NGOs, among others. From 2014 to 2015 he was lead mediator (Track II) in the Israeli-Palestinian water conflict, assigned by the Geneva Initiative and the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

profile_positions.description: Since its inception in 2013, the Water and Climate team has successfully acquired and implemented a multi-million euro project portfolio (with 12 projects in total) on water diplomacy, water governance and climate governance in various parts of the world. More information on our portfolio can be found at the link below. The team includes highly qualified experts with cross-disciplinary backgrounds and hands-on mediation experience. In the past three years the team published more than 30 academic and policy-relevant publications.
profile_positions.title: Head of Water Diplomacy & Climate Governance

profile_positions.company: The Hague Institute for Global Justice
profile_positions.description:
The challenges for water governance in the 21st century are large. Not only will it become more difficult to provide access to water to all (and particularly to vulnerable groups), also the multiple layers of global, national and local actors from traditional and non-traditional sectors will increasingly influence decision-making on the distribution of fresh water. This will lead to more water-related conflicts, sometimes small and covert, sometimes open and violent, between individuals but also between nation states.  
The ‘Water Diplomacy: Making Water Cooperation Work’-project will analyze the key determinants that contribute to the transformation of water conflicts to cooperation over water. It does so by undertaking state-of-the-art research, actively facilitating stakeholder dialogues, and by training facilitators in a number of case studies (e.g. Jordan and Ganges-Brahmaputra-Megna Basin). We choose to actively engage with the stakeholders involved in the water conflicts as to assert mutual learning, create trust and a profound dialogue. 
Next, key institutions in the domain of water diplomacy are involved in this project: Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI) and the newly established UNESCO Cat. II Centre on Water Cooperation in Sweden, Uppsala University (Sweden), UNESCO-IHE (The Netherlands), UFZ Helmholz Centre (Germany), IUCN-Asia, EcoPeace Middle East, and the Water Diplomacy Program at Tufts University, MIT and Harvard Law School. 
Based on our research and the thorough testing in practice we will strengthen existing tools or develop new tools suited to the needs of those stakeholders who deal with water conflicts on a daily basis.
profile_positions.title: Project Leader, Water Diplomacy: Making Water Cooperation Work

profile_positions.company: The Hague Institute for Global Justice
profile_positions.description:
The aim of this project is to contribute to sustainable economic development, climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction (DRR) through developing effective governance arrangements in a participatory process. The central tenet is to build adaptive capacity at multiple levels and to ensure social justice and human security in local climate action.

The project will be implemented in 2015-2017 by a Dutch consortium led by The Hague Institute for Global Justice, and its partners Deltares, Erasmus University, Wageningen University, together with our local counterparts the First Vice President’s Office and Department of Environment at Zanzibar.
profile_positions.title: Project Leader, Governance of Climate Adaptation in SIDS: Pilot Zanzibar

profile_positions.company: The Hague Institute for Global Justice
profile_positions.description: The Hague Institute supports Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI) on the development and application of a framework for political economy analysis (PEA) in transboundary river basins in Africa, funded by the World Bank.
profile_positions.title: Senior Expert, Framework for Political Economy Analysis of Transboundary Basins in Africa

profile_positions.company: The Hague Institute for Global Justice
profile_positions.description:
Yemen faces an acute water crisis amidst a range of other sources of instability. Despite much research and aid work in and on Yemen in recent years, significant knowledge gaps remain, especially concerning the use of national and local rules and procedures for solving water-related conflicts.

This project aims to better understand the political economy of Yemeni water management as a precondition for effective conflict prevention and resolution. It shall also support Yemen in achieving the corresponding water and sanitation targets under the UNDP Millennium Development Goals.
profile_positions.title: Project Director, Water Conflict Analysis and Intervention Framework for Yemen

profile_positions.description: Water Partner Foundation has been established in The Hague in 2008 as an independent non-profit organization, focused on international dissemination of knowledge and experiences with regard to good governance and sustainable development of water resources and the environment. Since its establishment, Water Partner Foundation has been involved in over ten strategic programs around the world. For example, we are currently responsible for management and implementation of a large Climate Adaptation Program in Vietnam in co-operation with international partners. For more information on our foundation please be referred to our website at www.waterpartner.org.
profile_positions.title: Director

profile_positions.description: The key objective of this pilot project is to develop an integrated and community-based risk management and climate change adaptation strategy for the Lower Vam Co River Basin in Vietnam. The strategy development is done by a participative and adaptive planning process at different levels (i.e. provincial, district and local level), supported by advanced decision support techniques. By doing so the project demonstrates the added value of applying a participative planning process for the integration of different interests and spatial challenges into one single strategy.
profile_positions.title: Project Manager of Participation in Climate Adaptation, Vam Co River Basin, Vietnam
